messages: 451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:39): I think user agents that do not expect HTML as their primary medium should not be bound by the HTML specification at all.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:40): Like when the content type is something other than text/html.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:41): My legal theory is that section 3.3.2 applies only to a transfor served as text/html to a user agent expecting HTML.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:41): XSLT processors are unaffected.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:42): Why anyone should do this remains a mystery to me.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:43): Another possibility is when elements from XHTML namespace are embedded in XML documents that are styled with CSS.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:44): In that case, behaviour may be taken from the XHTML definition.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:44): That would be true particularly for form controls and scripts, because XML does not allow scripts.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:45): (or rather, does not provide for scripts or any kind of interactivity explicitly.)
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:46): But even then, XSLT has a tendency of scattering the constituents of the output page across templates,
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:47): so the page as viewed from XSLT would be rather useless.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:48): Stylesheet is a legacy word to describe a transformation.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:48): It is really not appropriate any more.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:49): That does not mean that "transformation sheet" is good.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (17:50): It is a transformation, certainly not a sheet.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (17:57): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: how should i phrase it then?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:59): Hmm, turns out that tagNameState is the only thing that gets any practical benefit from not using charsUntil

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:08): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I would probably circumvent the problem by using a different example e.g. solving the roots of a quadratic using the quadratic formula
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:08): gives up for now, before he introduces more pointless bugs into html5lib
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (18:09): ironic that I was just talking about square roots in another channel
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:09): Otherwise I would say "using Pythagoras' theroem to solve for the hypotenuse <var>a</var> of a triangle of sides <var>b</var> and <var>c</var>"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:11): Wouldn't the quadratic formula take millions of lines of MathML and be impossible to read?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:11): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: that works, i'll use that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:11): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: yes
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:12): At least it's possible for a human to read the Pythagoras one
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:12): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: How many lines depends on how much whitespace you put in it :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:13): wonders if text in examples like "flavours of ice cream" should be translated to en-US

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:13): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: However the first law of MathML is that the total amount of markup needed to express a given concept is greater than the total amount of markup it was possible to use to express that concept
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:14): s/it was/anyone thought it was/

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:14): Anyway the example is clearly misleading, because you should expect 2<sup><var>n</var></sup> flavours of ice cream since they can choose whether or not to include each piped-in ingredient
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:14): (the first law of ontent MathML is roughly similar but with the words "much much greater")
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (18:24): You cannot solve roots and you cannot solve a hypotenuse.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (18:24): You can only solve problems, including special kinds of equations.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (18:25): You calculate roots and the length of the hypotenuse.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:25): Er yeah, I meant to say "solve /for/ the roots"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:25): appears to be parsing the spec in 12.6s now
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:26): Or, if you like, the quadratic
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (18:27): Solve what for the roots?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:27): The quadtratic, whatever it happens to be
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (18:27): Quadratic equation?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:28): yes. An equation can be solved. A root is a particular point on the solution.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:28): Hence "solving for the roots is both common and makes sense :)"
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (18:28): A root is a particular member OF the solution.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (18:28): The solution is a set of numbers, and calling them points is an exaggeration.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (18:29): "solving for the roots" misses the object.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:29): It seems equally valid to see the solution as a (discontinuous) line
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (18:30): That is redundant information.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (18:30): {(x1, 0), (x2, 0)} is much better handled as {x1, x2}
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:31): Well the roots are a special case you could equally say solve y=f(x) for y=5 or whatever
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:32): 451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa: There's no reason for a line to exist in a two-dimensional space
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:32): s/exist/only exist/
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (18:34): f(x)=5 are not roots.  f(x)-5 are roots, but it is a different equation.

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:37): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: The algorithm for setting document.domain should probably mention the fact that setting document.domain to a tld (or maybe a domain on the public suffix list?) is a security error
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:37): should probably send email
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (18:37): yeah i'll be adding that. send mail. :-)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:45): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: s/theroem/theorem/
